description: From earlier swip (with a short vowel), from Middle English swippen, swipen (“to move violently”), from Old English swipian, sweopian, swippan (“to scourge, strike, beat, lash”), from Proto-Germanic *swipōną, *swipjaną (“to move”), from Proto-Indo-European *sweyb- (“to bend, turn, swerve, sway, swing, sweep”). Cognate with German schwippen (“to whip”), Danish svippe (“to smack; crack a whip”), Icelandic svipa (“to whip; move swiftly”). Related to sweep, swoop.

entries.meaning: (countable) A quick grab, bat, or other motion with the hand or paw; a sweep.
(countable) A strong blow given with a sweeping motion, as with a bat or club.
(countable, graphical user interface) An act of interacting with a touch screen by drawing the finger rapidly across it.
(countable) An act of passing a swipecard through a card reader.
(countable, informal) A rough guess; an estimate or swag.
examples: Take a swipe at the answer, even if you're not sure.

entries.meaning: (countable, informal) An attack, insult or critical remark.
examples: The politician took a swipe at his opponents.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Poor, weak beer or other inferior alcoholic beverage; rotgut.

verbs.description: swipe (third-person singular simple present swipes, present participle swiping, simple past and past participle swiped)

examples: The cat swiped at the shoelace.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To strike with a strong blow in a sweeping motion.
(transitive) To scan or register by sliding (a swipecard etc.) through a reader.
examples: He swiped his card at the door.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, graphical user interface) To interact with a touch screen by drawing one's finger rapidly across it.
examples: Swipe left to hide the toolbar.

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal) To swipe right on (someone) on a dating application.
